Improved Sheet-Based Calculator

Introduction
The improved sheet-based calculator is a program which does mathematical expression calculations in a word-processing-like environment. It performs simple operations such as addition, subtraction, multiplication, division etc. It also allows users to assign value to a variable. It also able to calculate trigonometric function such as cos, sin, tan, log etc. The latest version allows users to define their own functions as well as graph said functions, use pi in calculations and set precision and the number of decimal places that is shown in their results.

Mathematical Operators Supported
Open Bracket (
Close Bracket )
Addition +
Subtraction -
Multiplication *
Division /
Power ^
Scientific Notation EXP

Functions Supported
Sine sin
Cosine cos
Tangent tan
Arc sine arcsin
Arc cosine arccos
Arc tangent arctan
Exponential ex
Logarithm log
Natural logarithm ln
Pi pi

Evaluating Mathematical Expressions
1) Type in the mathematical expression.
2) Highlight the expression.
3) Press the [Evaluate] button.
If you do not highlight anything, the calculator will attempt to evaluate the current line.
Example 1:
1 + 1 <-- highlight both and press evaluate
2 + 2 <-- highlight both and press evaluate
= 2.0 <-- answers will appear in the following lines
= 4.0
Example 2:
1 + 1
2 + 2 <-- cursor is in here, press evaluate
= 4.0 <-- calculator will only evaluate the current line

Using variables
1) Use the [=] sign to assign values to variables
Example
A = 1 <-- press evaluate
= 1.0
2) Simply refer to the variables in any expression and evaluate as before.
Example
A + 2
= 3.0

Defining Functions
1) Type in a function name followed by (x).
2) Type in "=" and define the function
3) Highlight the expression.
4) Press the [Evaluate] button.
If you do not highlight anything, the calculator will attempt to evaluate the current line.
Example 1:
f(x) = 3*x + 6 <-- highlight all and press evaluate
= 3*x+6 <-- answers will appear in the following lines

Calling Functions
1) The function must have been defined first. Once that is done, proceed with step 2.
2) Type in a function name followed by (x).
3) Highlight the expression.
4) Press the [Evaluate] button.
If you do not highlight anything, the calculator will attempt to evaluate the current line.
Example 1:
f(x) <-- highlight all and press evaluate
= 3*x+6 <-- answers will appear in the following lines

Solving Functions
1) The function must have been defined first. Once that is done, proceed with step 2.
2) Type in a function name followed by brackets with a number you wish to replace x with.
3) Highlight the expression.
4) Press the [Evaluate] button.
If you do not highlight anything, the calculator will attempt to evaluate the current line.
Example 1:
f(2) <-- highlight all and press evaluate
= 12.0 <-- answers will appear in the following lines

Graphing User-defined Functions
1) The function must have been defined first. Once that is done, proceed with step 2.
2) Type in a graph followed by square brackets with the user-defined function name inside.
3) Add a number to adjust the maximum x value of the graph if you wish to do so. 3) Highlight the expression.
4) Press the [Evaluate] button.
If you do not highlight anything, the calculator will attempt to evaluate the current line.
Example 1:
graph[f] <-- highlight all and press evaluate
graph[f 360] <-- highlight all and press evaluate

Changing settings
Certain settings such as the precise number of decimal places calculations should be calculated in (precision), and the number of decimal places answers are displayed in (DPlaces) can be changed by the user.

The default values are :
precision = 10000
DPlaces = 10

Use the buttons provided or type in the appropriate commands into the sheet to change them. Here are the steps to do so:

1) Type in precision followed by an "=", enter the number of decimal places you wish to calculate in
2) Type in DPlaces followed by an "=", enter the number of decimal places you wish for answers to be displayed in.
3) Highlight the expression.
4) Press the [Evaluate] button.
If you do not highlight anything, the calculator will attempt to evaluate the current line.
Example 1:
precision = 10 <-- highlight all and press evaluate
Example 2:
Dplaces = 3 <-- highlight all and press evaluate
60.16666+60 <-- highlight all and press evaluate
= 120.167 <-- answers will appear in the following lines
